name: Holmes's Chemistry Set
description: A portable chemistry set used by Sherlock Holmes for conducting chemical experiments and forensic tests.

content.title: Overview
content.body: Holmes’s chemistry set represents his scientific acumen and his reliance on empirical data in investigations. The portable kit allows him to perform a range of chemical reactions and tests, assisting his inquiries and giving him an advantage in solving crimes through analytical science.

content.title: Appearance
content.body: The chemistry set is depicted as a compact wooden or leather box containing an array of glass vials, reagents, burners, and basic laboratory equipment designed for field and study use. Its arrangement is orderly, with compartments for safely storing fragile chemical components, indicative of Holmes’s methodical and precise nature.

content.title: Function
content.body: Holmes uses the chemistry set to carry out experiments such as testing poisons, identifying substances, and analyzing unknown materials. This scientific approach differentiates him from other detectives and highlights the novel’s emphasis on modern investigative techniques.

content.title: History
content.body: Reflecting the Victorian era’s enthusiasm for scientific progress, the chemistry set embodies Holmes’s pioneering spirit in criminal investigation. It was notable in 'A Study in Scarlet' as an innovative tool reflecting the early fusion of chemistry and forensic science in detective work.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: The chemistry set is a key symbolic and practical item that underlines Holmes’s intellectual prowess. It features in scenes where Holmes deduces chemical properties or presence of substances crucial for identifying suspects or motives, thereby advancing the plot through scientific verification.

properties.contents: Various chemical reagents and laboratory tools
